bibl.title: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, October 6, 1921

div1.p: Caldwell thanks Carter for his informative and invaluable lecture. He reports on field work, problems with local customs, and migrant workers' susceptibility to yellow fever.

div1.head: Letter from Bert W. Caldwell to Henry Rose Carter, October 6, 1921

October 6th, 1921.
Dr. H.R. Carter
U.S.P.H. Service.
Dear Doctor Carter:
div1.p:
I want you to know how much benefit
you have conferred upon the campaign for the control of
Yellow Fever in Vera Cruz with you Lecture on "Yellow
Fever: Sanitary Measures for it Prophylaxis and Control.
I have read and re-read it with increasing interest and
I have distributed it among my force as widely as pos-
sible and have read it aloud to them on two occasions.

We have worked during the past year, with far
more success than we had hoped for. Nature has favored
us continually. The wet season held off a month longer
than usual and the “Northers” arrived on time and with
unuasual velocity. In the midst of the dangerous seas-
on the water system of the city became crippled and
tanks and other containers were emptied frequently.
While the number of water containers were increased
greatly, still the fact that they were emptied frequently helped us rather than
impeded our work.

We find in our work here, that on a scale of 100, the value of
emptying and cleaning the containers at each “vuelta” scores 55, the use of
fish scores 35 and oiling and other measures including permanently sealing
the container scores the other 10. Our sheet anchor is emptying and clean-
ing the container.

Our breeding in Barrils covers 52 percent of our breeding
places. Smaller containers the other 48; 1 1/2 per cent occurs in well and
cisterns which are fortunately few in numbers as compared with our total
containers, and the breeding in tanks, usually placed upon the house tops, is
negliglibe, and has never been greater than .59%.

One of our greatest troubles is the intensive breeding in
the “cineza” water, water in which the housewife has deposited ashes
to “break” the water for laundry purposes. This seems to conflict with your
statement that the stegomyia must have clean water to breed in. This water
is frequently dirty, and at times very strong with the wood ash lye. It is
usually contained in an “ola” of about five gallons capacity and in oil
tins of the same capacity. The container is rarely emptied and cleansed. Al-
ways a sufficient quantity of water remains to permit breeding. The house
wife cannot easily cover the container, refuses to have the water emptied and
will not go to the trouble of straining it and destroying the breeding focus.
The intensity of the larval and pupal infestation is maximum. Mosquito larvae
thrive in it. Fish placed in the container die promptly and so far I have
found no satisfactory method of handling this class of container. I would be
grateful for your suggestions.

One thing that enters largely into the distribution
of the aedes calopus and the increased number of foci is the mechanical
distribution of the larvae through carrying in containers from insted wells
and cisterns. or bani In Tampico last week, I located a large open well in the
centre of a patio which evidently supplied the people not only of that patio
but of others remote, with potable water. This well was litterally alive with
larvae, and while I was in the patio, nine water carriers came to the well
and drew water. In every containers were large numbers of pupa and
larvae and these were being transported all over the neighborhood. Of course
this particular well was cared for, but I am convinced that this method of

So far we have been able to keep Vera Cruz free
of yellow fever except those cases which have been sent
from the outside, to the Spanish Beneficencia and to
the Military Hospitals here. The troop movements have
been frequent and have carried the infection with them.
I believe that the final elimination of yellow fever
in Mexico is in sight, but hardly within the time limit
suggested in former years.

One of areas near Vera Cruz which seems to
have carried the disease over from year to year, is
responsible for the infection we have had since March
1st. This are is along the Papolopam River. The
area is fairly well populated. Several important towns
containing from ten to twelve thousand inhabitants lie
along its course of some 90 miles, extending from Al-
varado to the borders of Oaxaca. It is also ng this
river that the best sugar “ingenios” are located, and each
of them imports the bulk of its labor from the mountain
-ous states, during the cane cutting season. As many as
five thousand laborers come down yearly, with their
families, to work in the sugar fields. The laborers are all non-immune and
seems very susceptible to the disease. I am told that in former years, 40%
of this labor never returned to their homes but were stricken and died in
this area. Lyceaga, probably the most efficient of the Mexican sanitarians,
while he controlled Vera Cruz and the ports for several years, never seemed
to be satisfied with conditions in this area.

Lyster has been over recently and is now engaged on
the West Coast. He will be in New York before November first. Conner is down
at Merida, which has been free from yellow fever for the entire year. Vaughn
is in Guatemala. All of them are enjoying good health.

Mrs. Caldwell and my boy Henry have been with me for
the past three months. Mrs. Caldwell particularly desires to be remembered to
you and to Miss Carter.

I hope that you will be able to come down and look
this work over. You advice and counsel would be invaluable. While I think we
have made great progress during the past year, I am sure that there are many
little holes in the work, which you could, “chuck up,” and hasten the success of
the campaign greatly.
With every good wish, I remain,
div1.closer:
Respectfully, Bert W. Caldwell. Calle Constitucion No.13
vera Cruz Mexico.
